name: Diagnostic Radiology

points: 80% increase in workload from 2009-2020 for diagnostic radiologists
Severe radiologist shortage (14,000 active for entire US = 1:57,000 ratio)
Overwhelming RVU productivity pressure and quotas
Increasing imaging volume without proportional staffing increases
No time for mentorship or meaningful collegial interaction
Pressure to read more studies faster with same or fewer resources
44-65% burnout rate (male 44%, female 65%, some studies show 80%+)
98% of radiologists experience moral distress
Perception of providing substandard care due to excessive demands
Emotional exhaustion from relentless pace
Depersonalization and loss of purpose/enjoyment
Concerns about diagnostic errors from fatigue and stress
2 hours on EHR/desk work for every 1 hour of actual image interpretation
18+ hours per week on paperwork and administrative tasks
Poor EHR interoperability making it difficult to access outside records
Excessive inbox management with detailed portal responses required
Prior authorization consuming significant time for imaging orders
Government regulations and compliance burden (22% cite as burnout factor)
62% cite too many hours as primary burnout factor
Interventional radiologists working >80 hrs/week see 7x burnout increase
Unpredictable emergency call requirements
After-hours reading and night coverage demands
No protected time off (constantly clearing worklists)
Weekend and holiday coverage needs
41% cite lack of control/autonomy as major burnout factor
Corporate and private equity consolidation reducing independence
Administrators making clinical decisions without understanding radiology
Limited say in work processes, scheduling, and practice management
Erosion of traditional private practice model
Shift from practice ownership to employment status
Sedentary work in dark reading rooms for extended periods
Chronic musculoskeletal pain (low back pain, tenosynovitis)
Ergonomic challenges at workstations
Social isolation from PACS replacing face-to-face interactions
Reduced sense of belonging to healthcare team
Minimal direct patient contact affecting professional fulfillment

motivations: Better work-life balance with predictable, defined schedule
Teleradiology flexibility (remote work, location independence, control over schedule)
Reduced administrative burden and better EHR systems
Partnership opportunities in private practice with autonomy
Subspecialty focus rather than high-volume general radiology
Better technology access (AI tools, optimized PACS, ergonomic workstations)
Geographic relocation for lifestyle or family reasons
Higher compensation or better total package
Escape from social isolation to more collegial environment
Academic affiliation for teaching and research
Shift-based work (7 on/7 off, predictable hours)
Better mentorship and continuing education support
Escape from corporate medicine to physician-led practice

opening: Tell me about your current practice structure - private, hospital-employed, academic, or teleradiology?
Walk me through a typical day - what modalities are you reading and what's your volume like?
What's driving you to explore new opportunities at this point in your career?
Help me understand your current mix of general versus subspecialty work
painDiscovery: You mentioned [challenge] - help me understand how that's affecting your daily work and satisfaction
Tell me more about what led you to start looking - what was the tipping point?
Describe your current workload - daily study volume and how it feels sustainability-wise
Walk me through your administrative burden - time in EHR, prior auths, inbox management
Help me understand your work-life balance right now and what needs to change
Share with me your experience with burnout or fatigue in your current role
clinical: Describe your fellowship training and subspecialty interests or focus areas
Tell me about your comfort level with different modalities - CT, MRI, ultrasound, X-ray, fluoro
Help me understand your preferred case mix - what percentage general versus subspecialty?
Walk me through your experience with subspecialty areas - neuro, body, MSK, breast, etc.
Share your thoughts on on-site versus remote/teleradiology reading preferences
Tell me about your ideal daily study volume and case complexity
What's your experience with interventional procedures, if any?
How do you feel about call requirements and after-hours coverage?
motivation: When you think about your ideal practice environment, what does it look like?
Help me understand what would make a move worthwhile - your top priorities?
Tell me about your decision-making process for evaluating opportunities
Describe what work-life balance means to you in practical, specific terms
What aspects of radiology do you find most professionally rewarding?
compensation: Help me understand your complete compensation structure - base, productivity bonuses, benefits
When you think about your next position, what compensation package would make a move worthwhile?
Tell me about your financial goals and what's driving those expectations
How important is RVU-based versus salary-based compensation to you?
Share your thoughts on partnership opportunities or equity participation

commonChallenges.response: What daily study volume and case complexity would feel sustainable while maintaining quality?
Help me understand what appeals about full remote work - is it flexibility, location, or eliminating commute? Any concerns about isolation?
Walk me through specifically what's causing burnout - volume, autonomy, administrative burden? I want your next role to actually solve those problems
Tell me about your subspecialty focus and what percentage subspecialty versus general would be ideal for you
Help me understand what the location provides that's essential - family, schools, lifestyle? Teleradiology could potentially solve this
Share your thoughts on AI in radiology - do you see it as a threat or a tool to reduce repetitive work?
Walk me through what partnership means to you - autonomy, financial upside, long-term security, or something else?

challengingOpportunities: You mentioned preferring [location/setting]. Help me understand what NEED that solves - there might be other ways to meet that same need you haven't considered
I hear you want 100% subspecialty work. What if you did primarily subspecialty with some general mixed in - would that be worth exploring if the overall package was compelling?
You said work-life balance is critical. If I could show you a practice with defined shifts, no after-hours work, and predictable schedules, how would location flexibility factor in?
Many radiologists think they want traditional private practice until they realize the administrative burden. Have you considered employed positions that offer autonomy without business headaches?
You mentioned avoiding teleradiology. What if I could address your concerns about isolation and show you a model with strong peer support and mentorship?
